Question: Alright so I dont know much about Lexapro would you tell me more about it?
result:
Lexapro is a medication that belongs to a class of drugs
called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). It
is commonly used to treat depression and anxiety disorders.
Here are some important things to know about Lexapro:  - It
works by increasing the levels of serotonin in the brain,
which can improve mood and reduce anxiety. - It may take
several weeks for Lexapro to start working, so it's
important to be patient and continue taking it as
prescribed. - Common side effects of Lexapro include nausea,
headache, dizziness, and dry mouth. These side effects
usually go away on their own after a few days or weeks. -
Lexapro can interact with other medications, so it's
important to tell your doctor about all the medications you
are taking before starting Lexapro. - Lexapro is not
recommended for use in children under the age of 12. - If
you are pregnant or breastfeeding, talk to your doctor
before taking Lexapro, as it may not be safe for your baby.
I hope this information helps! Let me know if you have any
other questions.

Question: Also what is the oral option to get rid of scabies?
result:
The oral option to treat scabies is ivermectin, which is a
prescription medication that is taken by mouth. However, it
is important to note that topical treatments, such as
permethrin cream or lotion, are typically the first line of
treatment for scabies. It is best to consult with a
healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate
treatment plan for your specific case.

Question: Am I contagious with respiratory infection?
result:
Respiratory infections can be caused by a variety of viruses
and bacteria, some of which are contagious. It is important
to determine the specific cause of your infection to
determine if it is contagious or not. In general,
respiratory infections can be spread through coughing,
sneezing, or close contact with an infected person. To
prevent the spread of respiratory infections, it is
important to practice good hygiene, such as washing your
hands frequently and covering your mouth and nose when
coughing or sneezing. If you are experiencing symptoms of a
respiratory infection, it is recommended to stay home and
avoid close contact with others until you have fully
recovered.
